summary: nasopharyngeal aspirates were collected from cases and controls. pneumococcal density was quantified by lytA real-time polymerase-chain reaction. nasopharyngeal aspirates were collected from cases and controls. gram-positive bacterium Streptococcus pneumoniae (S. pneumoniae), a frequent colonizer of the child’s nasopharynx, remains one of the major killers of children globally despite extensive pneumococcal vaccination programs [1–3] colonizing pneumococci spread from their nasopharyngeal niche to normally sterile body sites and cause potentially life-threatening invasive pneumococcal disease (IPD) culture in non-invasive samples collected from the upper respiratory tract has been proposed as a candidate surrogate marker to discriminate from asymptomatic carriage. we aimed to determine whether pneumococcal load quantified with a lytA real-time PCR in NP aspirates taken from a rural pediatric population could be a marker of IPD. variables recorded in cases and controls included patient age, sex, height, weight, weight-for-age z (WAZ) score, nutritional status, recruitment season, co-infection with HIV or malaria, NP carriage (lytA positivity), NP serotype identification, serotype invasiveness potential. children with a weight-for-age z-score with a dispersion -1SD were considered to be undernourished. Frozen samples were shipped to hospital Sant Joan de Déu and Hospital Clinic, both in Barcelona (spain), where pneumococcal and respiratory virus studies were conducted. a duplex real-time PCR targeting the lytA gene of S. pneumoniae and the internal control targeting RNaseP of human cells were performed. patients with indistinguishable serotypes were excluded from the analysis of pneumococcal co-colonization. patients with indistinguishable serotypes were considered non-invasive for studying invasiveness potential. the area under the receiver operating characteristic curve (AUC-ROC) was the parameter used to select the most accurate predictive model and determine the optimal cut-off value of NP pneumococcal load that maximizes sensitivity and specificity. Statistical significance was set at a p-value of 0.05 and confidence intervals (CI) at 95% level. a NP aspirate was collected for both cases and controls to determine pneumococcal load and respiratory viral infection. two asymptomatic controls for IPD of the same age (+/-3 months) and sex were randomly selected in the community for each case from the DSS databases, and recruited during the period September-November 2012.
